awd_titl_txt: New Controller Design Approaches for Complex, Nonlinear Dynamic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create new theories and approaches for ensuring stable behavior and desired performance of complex dynamic systems. Some examples of such systems include network of power plants, interconnected electric vehicles, or biological systems such as normal cell physiology and the alterations that lead to human disease. This project will develop new theories and methods that can help design control systems for such systems based on better understanding of the intrinsic relationships between inherent characteristics of the system and their dynamic behaviors. The theories, tools and approaches can be readily used to solve a wide range of real-world engineering problems, including predicting evolution of damage in bones, developing more energy efficient control algorithms for power generation systems to reduce hazardous emissions, or designing better coordination control for a network of electric vehicles. The traditional approaches to design of control systems for complex nonlinear systems involve simplified model (linearization) of the system which inherently limits the performance of these systems. If successful, the outcome of the work will be a big leap towards finding better control methods for nonlinear systems. The project also has significant broader impacts. Through a structured research activity this project will enhance minority students' education at the University of Texas at San Antonio, a Hispanic serving institution. The project will also promote international collaboration among U.S.  students, faculty, and their peers in the global community. 

This project aims to develop sustained and systematic research to explore new theories and approaches for behavior analysis and controller design of inherently nonlinear dynamic systems. The new framework of multivariant homogeneity will be developed based on recent new concepts in defining homogeneity. The new generalized framework will be instrumental to characterize a boarder range of nonlinear dynamic systems. By establishing the homogeneous center manifold theory, the intrinsic link between the convergence rate of the system trajectory and the monotone homogeneity of the system will be discovered. The innovative design tools will lead to solutions to many open control problems for inherently nonlinear systems. The definitions, theories, and approaches in this project will add much-needed components to complete the theory of homogeneous systems, accelerate the research of control theory and dynamic systems, and facilitate new solutions to real-world engineering problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has attained a series of outcomes in exploring new theories and approaches for behavior analysis and controller design of nonlinear dynamic systems, applying new findings to real-world systems and other disciplines, and achieving our educational objectives.

For behavior analysis of nonlinear dynamic systems, we have come up with new methods to better understand the stability of these complex systems. One of our methods, the Particular Unstable Solution (PUS) method, helps us identify when certain complicated systems are unstable so we can avoid these types of structures. Another concept we?ve discovered is called Homogeneity with Strictly Decreasing Degrees (HSDD) which helps us figure out the stability of uncertain systems by looking at how different parts of the system change.

The next step for complex systems is to find controllers that make the system perform in desired ways. One particular approach we developed is called the nonlinearization technique, as opposed to the commonly known linearization technique. The nonlinearization technique enables the control of complex systems that cannot be effectively managed by traditional methods. Another noteworthy achievement is the integration of classical control methods with nonlinear control techniques to address uncertainties within systems. We have integrated certain classic controllers with new design features, which have surprisingly resolved some long-standing problems.

Nowadays, nearly all controllers are computer-implemented. However, this implementation is not straightforward, as traditional methods demand a significant computational burden and fast data acquisition devices. We've devised a novel co-design approach for sampled-data controllers that maintains a balance between sampling frequency and control gain. This method has proven successful in controlling various systems with input delay by employing memorized feedback controllers, showcasing enhanced transient performance compared to memory-less controllers. Moreover, we've designed a static sampled-data controller without a dynamic observer, further alleviating the computational load on control devices.

With substantial investments of time and resources by the project team, a wheeled-legged biped robot called Rowdy Robot was designed and prototyped for control testbed purposes. The Rowdy Robot is a versatile research platform that can be used for modeling, control, mechanical design, sensing, and other related research. Beyond its research utility, the Rowdy Robot featuring the UTSA mascot becomes a powerful instrument for public engagement in STEM education. The robot won first prize in a graduate student research showcase and garnered attention in the UTSA student newspaper.

Our research has far-reaching implications for various fields, fostering collaboration and new ways of thinking. Our control techniques have broad applications. The co-design approach has been successfully applied to aerospace engineering?s multi-agent systems, for surveillance, search, and rescue missions. Our contribution to power engineering is evident in the new control schemes for a PWM-based DC-DC buck converter system. In biomedical engineering, our new stability and oscillation criterion could greatly benefit as many medical models involve complex dynamics.

With the support of the Data Science Activities Supplement, we expanded the research scope beyond the realm of control. We discovered that conventional tools used for stability analysis and control design have significant relevance for deep neural networks. The solutions of nonlinear systems can enhance the accuracy of training data, rendering data-driven decisions more reliable. Our specialized homogeneous neural network structure, designed to effectively model intricate high-order dynamical systems, highlights the intricate interplay between neural networks and complex dynamic systems. While many control engineers have achieved success in applying deep learning technologies, the potential is even greater as more control engineers are encouraged to assume a more profound role by delving into the foundational connections between deep learning and control theory.

By providing research opportunities, mentorship, and support, the project has not only advanced knowledge but also contributed significantly to building an inclusive and skilled STEM workforce. This project has significantly impacted a diverse group of five PhD, four MS, and one BS students, including 3 Hispanic and 3 Female participants from underrepresented groups. Two PhD and four MS students successfully graduated during the project period, and all got employed or admitted to PhD program. After completing their PhDs, one PhD joined a tech company as an Electrical Engineer and another PhD became an assistant professor at a university. A Hispanic student resumed education after several years and earned an MS degree based on the research of this project, enabling teaching alongside engineering work.
